# ACISP 2025: Call for Papers

The 30th Australasian Conference on Information Security and Privacy (ACISP 2025) seeks original papers presenting novel research results in all aspects of information security and privacy. This 30th anniversary of ACISP will take place in Wollongong, Australia, from **July 14-16, 2025**. The conference welcomes papers presenting theories, techniques, implementations, applications, and practical experiences on a variety of topics.

ACISP 2025 will have two rounds of submission: Round one deadline on **November 6, 2024**, and Round two deadline on **February 19, 2025**.

## Topics of Interest

Topics include, but are not limited to:

*   Access Control
*   AI Security
*   Authentication
*   Blockchain technology
*   Cloud security
*   Cryptology
*   Cyber-physical systems security
*   Database security
*   Digital forensics
*   Key management
*   Lightweight security
*   IoT security
*   Network security
*   Privacy attacks and defenses
*   Privacy enhancing technologies
*   Security implementation
*   Security policy
*   Security protocols
*   Software security
*   System security
*   Trustworthy AI
*   Systematization of Knowledge (SoK) Papers

## Systematization of Knowledge (SoK) Papers

ACISP 2025 also solicits SoK papers that evaluate, systematize, and contextualize existing knowledge. These papers should include the prefix "SoK:" in the title and will be reviewed by the full PC based on their treatment of existing work and value to the community.

## Instructions for Authors

*   Submissions must be original, unpublished, and not submitted to another conference or journal.
*   Submissions must be fully anonymous (no author names, affiliations, acknowledgements, or obvious references).
*   Submissions must be written in English.
*   Papers can have at most **20 pages** including bibliography, using Springer's LNCS package with no changes to the style. Content beyond 20 pages can be placed in an Appendix, but papers must be intelligible and self-contained without appendices for PC members.
*   Papers not meeting the submission guidelines risk rejection.
*   The proceedings will be published by Springer-Verlag as a volume of the Lecture Notes in Computer Science series.
*   Authors of accepted papers must guarantee that at least one author will register and attend the conference to present their paper.
*   Author instructions and LaTeX/Word templates for LNCS publications can be found at: [https://www.springer.com/gp/computer-science/lncs/conference-proceedings-guidelines](https://www.springer.com/gp/computer-science/lncs/conference-proceedings-guidelines)

# AIED 2025: Call for Papers

The 26th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Education (AIED 2025) will take place between **July 22-26, 2025** in **Palermo, Italy**.

## Conference Theme

“**AI as a Catalyst for Inclusive, Personalised, and Ethical Education: Empowering Teachers and Students for an Equitable Future**”

AIED 2025 will be the 26th edition of this conference series, celebrating a quarter of a century advancing science and engineering of intelligent human-technology ecosystems that support learning. AIED is ranked A in CORE and is known for high-quality and innovative research on AI-assisted systems and cognitive science approaches for educational computing applications.

## Tracks

AIED 2025 is implementing a track-based system for its main paper submissions. The research tracks are:

*   **Track 1 – AIED architectures and tools**: Focuses on novel advances in the engineering and development of AIED systems, including proof-of-concepts and real-world implementations.
*   **Track 2 – Machine learning and Generative AI**: Describes advances in or applications of AI-based techniques within education, involving knowledge representation and machine learning, including generative AI.
*   **Track 3 – Learning, teaching and pedagogy**: Focuses on approaches to teaching, learning, and evaluations of AIED systems and environments related to pedagogical techniques, learning processes, and outcomes.
*   **Track 4 – Human-centered design and design-based research**: Addresses design principles for AIED systems, methods for designing them, and understanding contextual and individual factors informing user interactions.
*   **Track 5 – Teaching AI**: Involves methods, principles, or technologies for teaching AI or supporting the development of AI literacy.
*   **Track 6 – Ethics, Equity, and AIED in Society**: Examines AIED in relation to society, including the ethics of AIED, and designing AIED systems for a more equitable and just future.
*   **Track 7 – Theoretical aspects of AIED and AI-based modelling for Education**: Includes conceptual or theoretical models, methods, knowledge representation, and reasoning related to AIED research and systems.

## Diversity, Equity and Inclusion

The AIED Society values diversity, equity, and inclusion. Authors are encouraged to:

*   Write with care toward inclusive language.
*   Report methodology including descriptions of sample characteristics and any procedures for inclusive and representative sampling.
*   Consider how theoretical frameworks and findings relate to diversity, equity, and inclusion.
*   Address implications or appropriate interpretations of findings with respect to diversity, inclusion, and equity.

## Submission Instructions

### Contribution Types:

*   **Full paper submission:** Presents integrative reviews or original reports of substantive new work (theoretical, empirical, design, development, or deployment). Full papers will be presented as long oral talks. Papers submitted as full papers may be accepted as short papers.
*   **Short paper submission:** Describes novel and interesting results to the overall community. Short papers will be presented as short oral talks.

### Submission Policies:

*   Submissions must follow **Springer policies** on publication (including policies on the use of AI in the authoring process): [https://tinyurl.com/3rk3zj3v](https://tinyurl.com/3rk3zj3v).
*   Presenters of accepted papers are expected to be **on-site** to give their presentations and interact with the audience. An online streaming option will be set-up for remote observers.
*   **Scholarships** are available for researchers who lack funding to present at the conference.
*   Papers accepted for publication must have a **unique onsite author registration**.
*   There will be **NO downgrade path** from main submissions to posters.

### Other Submission Types (Details to be announced):

*   Blue Sky
*   WideAIED
*   Invited papers from the International Journal of AIED
*   Late-breaking results
*   Practitioners and Industry
*   Doctoral Consortium
*   Interactive events (e.g. demos)

## Review Process

*   All submissions will be reviewed by **three members of the program committee**, followed by a meta-review conducted by a senior member of the program committee (all double-masked).
*   Papers will be reviewed for **relevance, novelty, technical soundness, significance, and clarity of presentation**.
*   Work presented should not have been published previously or be under consideration elsewhere.

## Anonymity

The review process will be **double-masked**. Authors should:

*   Eliminate all information that could lead to their identification (names, contact information, affiliations, patents, names of approaches, frameworks, projects and/or systems).
*   Cite own prior work in the **third person**.
*   Eliminate acknowledgments and references to funding sources.

## Data Collection, Reporting, and Analysis

Authors should be clear and specific about the composition of human-sourced data, including participant demographics. Acknowledge demographic imbalances and discuss potential impacts. Steps taken to generate inclusive and representative samples are encouraged. Justify the inclusion/exclusion of demographic variables in analyses.

## Ethics

Authors should demonstrate awareness of how ethical issues (including equity, inclusion, accessibility) impact their data, methods, tools, approaches, products, and findings. Discuss differential impacts on demographic groups and communities.

## Submission Procedure and Publication

*   All submissions must be in **Springer format**. Papers not using the required format may be rejected without review.
*   Authors should use Springer's proceedings templates (LaTeX or Word).
*   Submissions are handled via **EasyChair**: [https://easychair.org/conferences/?conf=aied2025](https://easychair.org/conferences/?conf=aied2025).
*   Accepted papers will be published by **Springer Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence (LNAI)**.
*   **Paper Lengths**: 
    *   Full papers: **12 pages** excluding references.
    *   Short papers: **6 pages** excluding references.

The 17th ACM SIGCHI Symposium on Engineering Interactive Computing Systems (EICS 2025) is devoted to engineering interactive computing systems and their user interfaces, addressing software quality factors such as usability, user experience, reliability, and security. # Call for Papers

**EJC 2025: The 35th INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON INFORMATION MODELLING AND KNOWLEDGE BASES**

**Dates:** June 9-13, 2025
**Venue:** Faculty of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (building FEI), VSB - Technical University of Ostrava, Ostrava – Poruba, Czech Republic.

The conference aims to bring together experts from computer science, AI, and other disciplines interested in understanding and solving problems in information modelling and knowledge bases, as well as applying research results. The conference also seeks to identify and study new areas in these fields that require more attention.

## Important Dates

*   Submission deadline: **Not provided** (original deadlines of January 17, 2025 and February 5, 2025 were struck out and marked as extended, with no new date specified).
*   Registration deadline: **May 21, 2025**
*   Late registration begins: **May 22, 2025**

## Motivation

Information modelling is increasingly vital for researchers, designers, and users of information systems with artificial intelligence. As the volume and complexity of information grow, conceptual modelling remains a key sub-area. The conference serves as a platform for experts to discuss problems and applications, fostering an understanding of current and emerging trends in information modelling, knowledge bases, and AI, including philosophy, logic, cognitive science, knowledge management, linguistics, and cyber-physical modelling.

## Working Principles

The conference facilitates discussion, allows ample presentation time, and limits participation to **50 individuals** and **30 papers** to ensure focused interaction.

## Submission Categories

The conference will have three categories of presentations:

*   **Full papers**
*   **Short papers**
*   **Position papers**

All accepted and presented papers (full/short/position) are published in the conference preprint (e-book with ISSN/ISBN) and subsequently in a final journal-paper publication.

## Suggested Topics

Topics include, but are not limited to:

*   **Conceptual modelling:** Modelling and specification languages; Domain-specific conceptual modelling; Concepts, concept theories and ontologies; Conceptual modelling of large and heterogeneous systems; Conceptual modelling of spatial, temporal and semantic data; Methods for developing, validating and communicating conceptual models.
*   **Knowledge and information modelling and discovery:** Knowledge discovery, knowledge representation and knowledge management; Advanced data mining and analysis methods; Conceptions of knowledge and information; Modelling information requirements; Intelligent information systems; Information recognition and information modelling.
*   **Linguistic modelling:** Models of HCI; Information delivery to users; Intelligent informal querying; Linguistic foundation of information and knowledge; Fuzzy linguistic models; Philosophical and linguistic foundations of conceptual models.
*   **Cross-cultural communication and social computing:** Cross-cultural support systems; Integration, evolution and migration of systems; Collaborative societies; Multicultural web-based software systems; Intercultural collaboration and support systems; Social computing, behavior modelling and prediction.
*   **Environmental modelling and engineering:** Environmental information systems (architecture); Spatial, temporal and observational information systems; Large-scale environmental systems; Collaborative knowledge base systems; Agent concepts and conceptualization; Hazard prediction, prevention and steering systems.
*   **Multimedia data modelling and systems:** Modelling multimedia information and knowledge; Content-based multimedia data management; Content-based multimedia retrieval; Privacy and context enhancing technologies; Semantics and pragmatics of multimedia data; Metadata for multimedia information systems.
*   **AI System Modelling:** Cyber and Physical System Modelling; Image Processing; Natural Language Processing; Computer Vision; Biological Analysis; Responsible AI.

## Publication

*   Conference preprint (e-book with ISSN/ISBN) by local organizers.
*   Final publication in the Series “Frontiers in Artificial Intelligence” by IOS Press (Amsterdam).
*   Opportunity for authors to improve papers based on conference feedback.
*   Invitation to publish in ECTI-Transactions on Computer and Information Technology (ECTI-CIT) selected by the Editorial Board.

## Registration Fees

*   The conference fee includes one publication.
*   Publication of an additional paper: **300 EUR**.
*   Late registration fee (from May 22, 2025): **670 EUR**.
*   Transaction fees should be covered by the payer.
*   Note: The regular registration fee is not explicitly stated.

## Author's Instructions

Authors must present their paper at the conference. Detailed instructions can be found at href="authors_instructions.html" - Author's Instructions.

## Contact Information

For editorial issues, please contact the editing committee via email: ejc2025ostrava@gmail.com.

# ENASE 2025: Call for Papers

The International Conference on Evaluation of Novel Approaches to Software Engineering (ENASE 2025) is scheduled to take place from **April 4-6, 2025**, in **Porto, Portugal**.

ENASE 2025 is sponsored by INSTICC and is held in conjunction with other conferences: ICEIS 2025, ICT4AWE 2025, VEHITS 2025, IoTBDS 2025, and FEMIB 2025. Registration for ENASE allows free access to the co-located conferences as a non-speaker.

While the conference is primarily in-person, remote presentation options are available for speakers unable to travel to the venue.

## Scope

The mission of ENASE is to serve as a premier international forum for the discussion and publication of research findings and industry experiences concerning novel approaches in software engineering. It addresses the evolution of systems and software thinking influenced by contemporary computing paradigms such as e-services, cloud computing, mobile connectivity, business processes, and societal participation. By evaluating the latest research on novel approaches against systems and software quality criteria, ENASE aims to advance knowledge and research in software engineering, particularly in service-oriented, business-process driven, and ubiquitous mobile computing.

ENASE seeks to identify promising trends and propose new directions for researchers and practitioners involved in large-scale systems and software development, integration, deployment, delivery, maintenance, and evolution.

# European Symposium on Algorithms (ESA) 2025: Call for Papers

The European Symposium on Algorithms (ESA) is one of the premier conferences on algorithms. It is organized in collaboration with the European Association for Theoretical Computer Science (EATCS) and is a part of ALGO 2025, to be held in Warsaw, Poland.

## Scope

The symposium seeks original algorithmic contributions for problems with relevant theoretical and/or practical applications.

## Submission Tracks

*   **Track A:** Papers with a strong emphasis on the theoretical analysis of algorithms.
*   **Track B:** Papers reporting the results of extensive experimental evaluations and/or providing original contributions to the engineering of algorithms for practical applications.
*   **Track S:** Papers that prove or explain results, possibly already known, in a particularly clear, simple, or elegant way.

## Awards

There will be a **Best Student Paper Award** and a **Best Paper Award**, both sponsored by EATCS. For the Best Student Paper Award, all authors must be students (including PhD candidates) at the time of submission.

## Submission System and Proceedings

*   Papers should be submitted electronically via the href="https://easychair.org/conferences/?conf=esa2025" - EasyChair submission system .
*   The ESA 2025 proceedings will be published in the Leibniz International Proceedings in Informatics (LIPIcs) series.

## Submission Guidelines

*   Authors are invited to submit an extended abstract or full paper.
*   Submissions must be formatted in accordance with the LIPIcs proceedings guidelines and may not exceed **500 lines of text**.
*   Authors must use the LaTeX class file `socg-lipics-v2021.cls` (version 0.9, updated 2022) and `lipics-v2021` (version 3.1.3, updated 2023-05-12).
*   Proofs omitted due to the line constraint must be placed in an appendix. This appendix will not be published in the proceedings. The main part of the submission should contain a clear technical presentation of the paper's merits.
*   Submissions deviating significantly from these guidelines risk being rejected without consideration.
*   Results previously published or scheduled for publication elsewhere should not be submitted.
*   Simultaneous submission to other conferences with published proceedings, journals, or multiple tracks of ESA 2025 is not permitted.
*   At least one author of each accepted paper must register for ALGO 2025, attend the conference on-site, and present the paper. Papers not presented may risk being removed from the final proceedings.

## Double-Blind Reviewing

The conference employs a lightweight double-blind reviewing process. Submissions should not reveal the identity of the authors (names, affiliations, email addresses). References to own work must be in the third person. Important references should not be omitted or anonymized.

## Conflict of Interest (CoI)

Authors must indicate any Conflict of Interest (CoI) with PC members, including family ties, advisor/mentee relationships, same affiliation, prior harassment incidents, owing favors, or frequent/recent collaboration where objectivity is questionable.

# ESOP 2025: Call for Papers

**ESOP 2025**, the 34th European Symposium on Programming, is part of the ETAPS 2025 joint international conferences.

**Dates:** Main Conference: **May 5–8, 2025**. Satellite Events: May 3–4, 2025.
**Location:** Hamilton, Canada, hosted by McMaster University.

## Scope

ESOP is an annual conference devoted to fundamental issues in the specification, design, analysis, and implementation of programming languages and systems. ESOP seeks contributions on all aspects of programming language research, including but not limited to:

*   programming paradigms and styles
*   methods and tools to specify and reason about programs and languages
*   programming language foundations
*   methods and tools for implementation, concurrency and distribution
*   applications and emerging topics

Contributions bridging the gap between theory and practice are particularly welcome.

## Submission Rounds and Important Dates

ESOP 2025 features a two-round submission scheme:

### Round 1

*   **Submission deadline:** **May 30, 2024**
*   **Rebuttal:** July 23–25, 2024
*   **Notification:** August 8, 2024

### Round 2

*   **Submission deadline:** **October 10, 2024** (submitted papers can be polished until October 14, 2024)
*   **Rebuttal:** December 3–5, 2024
*   **Notification:** December 19, 2024

## Submission Categories

ESOP 2025 solicits three forms of contributions:

1.  **Research Papers:** Articles advancing the state-of-the-art on the theory and practice of programming languages and systems. Submissions may be formatted in Springer’s LNCS, ACM’s PACMPL, or ACM’s TOPLAS. # Call for Paper

EuroMPI/USA 2025 will focus on advancing the ubiquitous Message Passing Interface (MPI) model and specification of parallel programming. The conference will also encompass extensions and alternative interfaces for high-performance heterogeneous and hybrid systems, benchmarks, tools, parallel I/O, fault tolerance, and parallel applications using MPI and other interfaces.

EuroMPI/USA 2025 will be hosted by the **University of North Carolina, Charlotte** and will be co-located with [IWOMP 2025](https://www.iwomp.org/) (October 1 - October 3, 2025), with joint tutorials and opportunities for interaction between the two communities. The MPI Forum will also meet following the conference.

Through the presentation of full papers, position papers, posters, and invited talks, the meeting will provide ample opportunities for attendees to interact and share ideas and experiences to contribute to the improvement and furthering of message-passing and related parallel programming paradigms. Having EuroMPI, IWOMP and the MPI Forum grouped together enables attendees to interact and share ideas and experiences to contribute to the improvement and furthering of message-passing, shared-memory parallelism, and related parallel programming paradigms -- and their combined usage.

## Topics of Interest

We invite high-quality, full and short paper submissions on all topics related to message-passing parallel programming with MPI and related or competing models. Topics of interest include, but are not limited to:

*   **Implementation Issues and Algorithms:** Efficient and scalable implementations of message-passing constructs.
*   **Architectures and systems:** Towards exascale computing, efficient use of accelerators and other features of modern, large-scale systems, hardware-software interaction.
*   **Message Passing for accelerator-based compute architectures**, including multi-GPU, TPU, and AI-accelerator systems.
*   **Programming models and paradigms** related to MPI targeting large-scale, parallel, distributed memory systems, hierarchical and hybrid models, partitioned global address space (PGAS) models.
*   **Extensions to and shortcomings of MPI:** alternative interfaces and solutions.
*   **New, parallel (MPI-)I/O mechanisms optimizations**.
*   **Hybrid and heterogeneous programming** with MPI and other interfaces.
*   **Message passing interface support for data-intensive parallel applications**.
*   **Fault tolerance** in message-passing implementations and systems.
*   **MPI parallel programming in clouds and non-dedicated systems**.
*   **Performance evaluation** for MPI and MPI-based applications.
*   **Automatic performance tuning** of applications and implementations.
*   **Verification** of message-passing applications and protocols.
*   **Applications using advanced message passing**, in particular in computational science and scientific computing.
*   **Parallel algorithms** in the message-passing paradigm.
*   **Interactions** between the message-passing library and runtime systems.
*   **Use of MPI in Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Large Language Models (LLM)** and its challenges
*   **Integration and comparisons** with competing industry standards (e.g., NCCL, RCCL)

## Submission Types

*   **Full Papers**
*   **Short Papers**
*   **Position Papers**
*   **Posters**

## Important Dates

All times are **Anywhere on Earth (AoE)**:

*   **Abstract deadline (extended):** June 6, 2025
*   **Submission deadline (extended):** June 6, 2025
*   **Paper notification:** July 14, 2025
*   **Poster submission deadline:** July 25, 2025
*   **Poster notification:** August 8, 2025

## Submission Guidelines

### Papers

*   Papers must use the **Springer LNCS proceedings template**. An [Overleaf template](https://www.overleaf.com/latex/learn/nextsteps) is available.
*   **Full papers:** Should be at least 12 and at most 16 pages, including figures and tables but excluding references.
*   **Short papers:** May be between 6 and 9 pages.
*   Margins, spacing, and font sizes should not be modified from the template.
*   Authors should submit their work through the [EuroMPI/USA 2025 submission site at easychair](https://easychair.org/conferences?conf=eurompiusa2025).
*   At least one of the authors of each paper accepted for presentation must be registered.

### Posters

*   We welcome the submission of abstracts for posters to be presented during a dedicated poster session.
*   These abstracts should not exceed **2 pages** (excluding references).
*   Abstracts should use the **Springer LNCS proceedings template**.
*   Submit through the [EasyChair submission site](https://easychair.org/conferences?conf=eurompiusa2025).
*   **Deadline for submitting poster abstracts:** July 25, 2025.

## Review Process

Papers will be reviewed for quality, originality, clarity, correctness, technical strength, and relevance to the topics of the meeting. Each paper will receive at least three reviews from members of the program committee. Reviews are single-anonymous (authors' names will be seen by the program committee).

## Publication

A few of the best papers will be selected by the program committee and recommended for publication in a **EuroMPI/USA 2025 Special Issue of a Journal**. These papers will go through a separate round of reviews and are intended as extended, more polished archival versions of the conference versions.

Papers not accepted as full papers may be recommended for poster presentations. High-quality short papers will be included in the proceedings. Posters will be published informally on the website, but are not intended to appear in the regular conference proceedings.

# EuroS&P 2025: Call for Papers

The IEEE European Symposium on Security and Privacy (Euro S&P) is a premier forum for computer security and privacy research, presenting the latest developments and bringing together researchers and practitioners.

## Scope

We solicit previously unpublished papers offering novel research contributions in security or privacy, as well as Systematization of Knowledge (SoK) papers that systematize previous results. EuroS&P is interested in all aspects of applied computer security and privacy. We especially encourage papers that are far-reaching and risky, provided those papers show sufficient promise for creating interesting discussions and usefully questioning widely-held beliefs. Papers without a clear connection to security or privacy will be considered out of scope and may be rejected without full review.

## Conference Expectations and Review Process

*   **Single-Track:** While historically single-track, the conference may adjust based on submission volume.
*   **Rigorous Review:** Aiming for a rigorous and thorough review process, accepting papers with scientific merit.
*   **Revision Option:** Papers with a potential path for acceptance after revision may be invited for revision within four weeks of notification. Revised papers will be re-reviewed.
*   **Per-Reviewer Responses (New in 2025):** Reviewers will provide specific questions for authors to focus on in their responses, improving communication and timely feedback.
*   **Meta Reviews (Returning from 2024):** Publicly available meta reviews will outline PC reasons for acceptance and identified limitations.

## Systematization of Knowledge (SoK) Papers

We solicit SoK papers that evaluate, systematize, and contextualize existing knowledge. Suitable papers provide new viewpoints, challenge beliefs with evidence, or present convincing taxonomies. Survey papers without such insights are not appropriate. SoK papers should be prefixed with "SoK:" in the title and will be reviewed to the same standards as traditional research papers, with emphasis on community value.

## Paper Awards

Outstanding papers will be selected by the program committee and announced at the symposium.

## Important Dates

All deadlines are Anywhere on Earth (AoE = UTC-12h).

### Research Papers

*   **Registration deadline (incl. topics and abstracts):** 21 October 2024 (Monday)
*   **Submission deadline:** 24 October 2024 (Thursday)
*   **Early rejection notification:** 11 December 2024 (Wednesday)
*   **R1 Rebuttal period:** 12 December - 16 December 2024 (Monday)
*   **R2 Rebuttal period:** 20 - 23 January 2025 (Monday to Thursday)
*   **Author Notification:** 13 February 2025 (Thursday)
*   **Submission of revised papers:** 20 March 2025 (Thursday)
*   **Revision Decisions:** 3 April 2025 (Thursday)
*   **Camera-ready deadline:** tentatively: 17 April 2025 (Thursday)

### Conference

*   **Venice, Italy:** 30 June - 4 July 2025

## Proactive Prevention of Harm

Authors must carefully consider and address potential harms associated with their research and its publication. Failure to adequately discuss such harms may result in rejection. This includes documenting how risks were addressed and mitigated, considering impacts on deployed systems, data collection safety, and responsible disclosure practices. Papers should include a clear statement on how the research benefit outweighs potential harms and the safety measures taken.

If IRB consultation is available, it is expected to be appropriately consulted and documented. IRB approval does not absolve researchers from considering ethical aspects or guarantee PC acceptance.

Consult resources like "Common Pitfalls in Writing about Security and Privacy Human Subjects Experiments" and the "Menlo Report" for guidance.

## Open Science Expectations

Researchers are expected to maximize the scientific and community value of their work by making it as open as possible. By default, all reproducible materials (code, data) must be released under an open source license. Exceptions apply for malware, protected human subject data, or proprietary data. All submissions must include a clear Data Availability statement explaining sharing plans or reasons for not sharing. Papers failing to meet commitments may be removed from the conference.

## Plagiarism and Duplicate Submission

All submissions must be original work. Plagiarism (of others or self) will be grounds for rejection. Overlap with previously published or simultaneously submitted papers must be clearly documented. Simultaneous submission of the same or substantially similar paper to another venue is not allowed and will be grounds for automatic rejection.

## Anonymous Submission

*   Papers must be submitted anonymously: no author names or affiliations on the title page, and authors must avoid revealing their identity in the text.
*   Refer to your previous work in the third person.
*   Blind references only if a third-person reference is infeasible.
*   Use anonymous services for hosting code/data (e.g., Anonymous Github, not Github or Google Drive).
*   Contact PC chairs with any questions. Papers not properly anonymized may be rejected without review.
*   Authors may post preprints to archives like arXiv.
*   Papers blatantly violating anonymity may be rejected by the Program Chairs.

## Reviews from Prior Submissions

Authors may optionally submit a separate, anonymized document of prior reviews (from another conference) along with a description of how those reviews were addressed. This supplementary material is visible to reviewers only after they submit their own initial review.

## Page Limit and Formatting

*   **Page Limit:** Maximum 13 pages of body text. Unlimited additional pages for references and appendices. Data Availability statement is part of the appendix.
*   **Formatting:** Must use LaTeX in A4 format with the provided `eurosp-template.zip`. Do not use other IEEE templates.
*   **Format:** Submissions must be in Portable Document Format (.pdf).
*   **Rendering:** Ensure documents render correctly in Adobe Reader XI and when printed in black and white. Unusual fonts, images, or figures may cause issues.
*   Failure to adhere to page limit and formatting requirements can lead to rejection without review.

## Conference Submission Server

Papers must be submitted at [https://hotcrp.eurosp2025.ieee-security.org](https://hotcrp.eurosp2025.ieee-security.org) and can be updated until the deadline.

## Publication and Presentation

Authors are responsible for publication clearances. At least one author of an accepted paper must present at the conference. In-person attendance is expected. If travel is impossible, at least one author must register, but the presentation may be skipped or replaced by a linked video presentation if a replacement presenter cannot be found.

*   **Full paper:** Approximately 12 to 15 pages, detailing a full case study or research study.
*   **Short paper:** Approximately 6-8 pages, addressing an important case study or research result.
*   **Key statement / poster:** Approximately 4 pages, making a key experience/best practice statement.

Selected extended papers will be published in the **Wiley Journal of Software: Evolution and Process Series**. A selected set of papers will be published in the **Springer CCIS Series**.

# EvoMUSART 2025: Call for Papers

The 14th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Music, Sound, Art and Design (EvoMUSART) 2025 is a multidisciplinary conference that brings together researchers working on the application of Artificial Intelligence techniques in creative and artistic fields. The conference will be held from **May 18, 2025 to May 22, 2025**.

## Topics of Interest and Contributions

Submissions should concern the use of Artificial Intelligence techniques (e.g., Evolutionary Computation, Artificial Neural Networks, Artificial Life, Machine Learning, Deep Learning, Swarm Intelligence) in the generation, analysis, and interpretation of art, music, design, architecture, and other creative and artistic fields. Topics include, but are not limited to:

### Generation

*   Systems that create drawings, images, animations, sculptures, poetry, text, designs, webpages, buildings, etc.
*   Systems that create musical pieces, sounds, instruments, voices, sound analysis, etc.
*   Systems that create artefacts such as game content, architecture, furniture, based on aesthetic and functional criteria.
*   Robotic-based Evolutionary Art and Music.
*   Other related artificial intelligence or generative techniques in Computer Music, Computer Art, etc.

### Automation

*   Techniques for automatic fitness assignment.
*   Systems where analysis or interpretation of artworks is used with AI to produce novel objects.
*   Systems using AI approaches to analyze image, music, sound, sculpture, or other artistic objects.

### Computer Aided Creativity and Computational Creativity

*   Systems where AI promotes human creativity.
*   New ways of integrating the user in the evolutionary cycle.
*   Analysis and evaluation of artistic potential, processes, and resulting artefacts.
*   Collaborative distributed artificial art environments.
*   Contextualisation of creative AI in cultural, economic, social, political, or ecological discourse.

### Theory

*   Computational Aesthetics, Experimental Aesthetics; Emotional Response, Surprise, Novelty.
*   Representation techniques.
*   Surveys of the current state-of-the-art, identification of weaknesses and strengths, comparative analysis and classification.
*   Validation methodologies.
*   Studies on the applicability of these techniques to related areas.
*   New models designed to promote the creative potential of biologically inspired computation.

# EWSN 2025: Call for Papers

The International Conference on Embedded Wireless Systems and Networks (EWSN) is a highly selective single-track international conference focusing on the latest research in embedded systems and wireless networking and their role as key enablers for visionary scenarios such as the Internet of Things and Cyber-Physical Systems.

EWSN 2025 will be held in **Leuven, Belgium**, from **September 22 – 24, 2025**, hosted by KU Leuven.

## Feature Topic: Artificial Intelligence of Things (AIoT)

While the conference welcomes all papers within the scope, this year’s edition of EWSN will also highlight a feature topic in Artificial Intelligence of Things (AIoT). AIoT represents the convergence of two cutting-edge fields, artificial intelligence and the Internet of Things (IoT), leading to groundbreaking innovations across various sectors. The conference will seek contributions in this general area and feature keynote speakers with this focus.

## Topics of Interest

Specific topics for the conference include (but are not exclusively limited to):

*   AI-operated wireless sensing, actuation, and control systems
*   Applications and opportunities for networked embedded systems in developing countries
*   Applications of wireless embedded networks in various domains: health, automation, manufacturing, transportation, etc.
*   Architectures and infrastructures for edge-cloud solutions that integrate networked embedded systems
*   Communication and networking for wireless and embedded systems
*   Computing architectures for networked embedded systems
*   Dependability in wireless systems, including reliability, availability, safety, and real-time guarantees
*   Edge/embedded intelligence paradigms, models, and techniques for networked embedded systems
*   Foundation models and generative AI for networked embedded systems
*   TinyML and on-device AI for networked embedded systems
*   Empirical studies, measurement, validation, deployment, and experience reports
*   Human-centric interaction with wireless and embedded systems
*   Localization and context-awareness for embedded wireless systems and networks
*   Modeling, simulation, and measurement tools for wireless systems and applications
*   Neuromorphic computing
*   Next-generation wireless networks, including 6G
*   New communication techniques for embedded systems (Wi-Fi HaLow, NearLink, etc.)
*   Operating systems, middleware, and services for networked embedded systems
*   Privacy and security in networked embedded systems and applications
*   Processing, storage, and management of data in embedded wireless networks
*   Sustainable applications of networked embedded systems (low-power operation, energy harvesting, etc.)
*   Embedded systems for joint sensing and communication with mmwave, Terahertz, Wi-Fi, visible light, etc.

## Submission Details

*   **Originality:** Any paper submitted to EWSN 2025 must be original (i.e., not previously published) and should not have been published, accepted for publication, or be under review by any other venue.
*   **Paper Types:** The conference will accept **Full Papers** (max 12 pages) and **Short Papers** (max 6 pages).
    *   Short papers are intended to present preliminary research results or advocate for new research directions; their titles should be prepended with “Vision paper: / Position paper: / WiP paper” when submitted for review and in the final proceedings.
*   **Review Policy:** EWSN 2025 will use a **double-anonymous review policy**. Authors are instructed to not include their names, affiliations, and contact information on the manuscript they submit for review. The content of the paper must also be anonymized.
*   **arXiv Submissions:** Submission to arXiv (or similar) is allowed, provided cross-citations are not made. You MAY post a version of your paper on arXiv that lists the names of authors, but you MAY NOT reference the arXiv version from the paper submitted for review at EWSN, nor reference your submitted EWSN paper in the arXiv paper or any other papers submitted for review at other conferences.
*   **Submission System:** Submissions are via HotCRP: [https://ewsn25.hotcrp.com/](https://ewsn25.hotcrp.com/)
*   **Decisions:** Decisions will be: accept, reject, or one-shot revision. Papers receiving a “one-shot revision” for the winter deadline will be invited to submit a revised paper by the summer deadline.
*   **Formatting:** Pages must use 8.5″ x 11″ (letter) two-column format, using 10-point type on 11-point leading, with a maximum text block of 7″ wide x 9″ deep with an inter-column spacing of .25″. Submissions with a page size of 11.7 x 8.3 ” (297 x 210 mm / A4) will not be accepted. The page limits include figures, tables, and references. Authors may use the [EWSN 2025 template](https://www.overleaf.com/latex/templates/ews-template/wjkxczrznnhj) (adapted from ACM templates).
*   **Indexing:** All accepted papers will be indexed in the ACM Digital Library, SCOPUS, and other prominent digital libraries.

-   Scalability and interoperability of cryptocurrencies
-   Security of banking, financial services, and electronic commerce
-   Security of peer-to-peer networks
-   Smart contracts and financial instruments
-   Smartcards, secure tokens, and secure hardware
-   Surveillance and tracking
-   System security
-   Trusted execution environments (TEE), their security and applications
-   Usability and security
-   Web security
-   Zero-knowledge proofs

> Remember! The "crypto" in financial cryptography covers more than just your digital cash—it's also the secret sauce behind keeping your spy-level messages safe!

## Submission Categories

Contributions are sought in the following categories:

### Research Papers

-   **Regular papers:** 15 pages + references and appendices.
-   **Short papers:** 8 pages + references; no appendices.
-   **Systematization of Knowledge (SoK) papers:** 20 pages + references and appendices.

### Workshop Proposals

-   2 pages in length.

### Tutorial Proposals

-   2 pages in length.

## Submission Guidelines

### General Information

For each accepted paper, the conference requires at least one registration at the general or academic rate, and paper authors must sign the [IFCA copyright form](http://ifca.ai/documents/copyright.html) when submitting the final version. Alternatively, individual papers can be published as fully open access—the publisher charges authors a fee for this.

### Format

Papers must be formatted in standard [LNCS format (templates)](https://www.springer.com/gp/computer-science/lncs/conference-proceedings-guidelines) and submitted as PDF files. Submissions in other formats will be rejected. All papers must be submitted electronically according to the instructions and forms found here and at the submission site.

### Anonymous Submission

Regular and short research paper submissions as well as SoKs must be anonymized with no author names, affiliations, acknowledgments, or obvious references. Failure to properly anonymize submitted papers is grounds for a desk rejection without review. It is acceptable (but by no means required) for submitted papers to be published online in non-anonymous form (e.g., on authors' websites or archives like the Cryptology ePrint Archive or arXiv.org). Program committee members will be instructed not to actively seek to de-anonymize papers.

### Original Submissions

Authors may submit only work that does not substantially overlap with work that is currently submitted or has been accepted for publication to any other peer-reviewed conference/workshop with proceedings or a journal. We consider double submission serious research fraud and will treat it as such. Note that it is acceptable for papers to appear in non-peer-reviewed formats (for example, as technical reports or in online archives such as ePrint). In case of doubt contact the program chairs for any clarifications.

### Ethics and Etiquette

Authors are required to read and follow this [information on ethics and etiquette](https://www.ifca.ai/docs/ethics-etiquette.html).

### Conflict of Interest

Authors must report in the submission site any conflicts with program committee members. A conflict exists if an author has the same affiliation as a committee member, has ever acted as their PhD supervisor or been supervised by them, has a close personal relationship with them, or if they have been co-authors on a paper within the past two years. PC chairs are not allowed to submit papers where they appear as (co-)authors.

PC members will not be able to review, read the reviews of, or participate in discussions of papers they are conflicted with. The review process for papers conflicted with both PC chairs will be managed by another PC member designated as the "conflict chair".

### Submission Portals

-   Research paper submissions must be uploaded through the [conference submission website](https://crypto.unibe.ch/fc25/).
-   Workshop and tutorial proposals should be sent by email to [fc25workshops@ifca.ai](mailto:fc25workshops@ifca.ai), and should not be anonymized.

## Evaluation Criteria

### Regular Research Papers

Research papers should describe novel, previously unpublished scientific contributions to the field, and they will be subject to rigorous peer review. Accepted submissions will be included in the conference proceedings to be published in the Springer-Verlag Lecture Notes in Computer Science (LNCS) series. Submissions are limited to **15 pages** in standard LNCS format excluding references and appendices. A total page restriction may apply for the printed proceedings version. Committee members are not required to read the appendices, so the full papers should be intelligible without them.

### Short Papers

Short papers are also subject to peer review; however, the intention is to encourage authors to introduce work in progress, novel applications, and corporate/industrial experiences. Short papers will be evaluated with a focus on novelty and potential for sparking participants' interest and future research avenues. Short paper submissions are limited to **8 pages** in standard LNCS format, excluding references. The title for short papers must begin with the text "Short Paper:". Accepted submissions will be included in the conference proceedings. The authors of some submissions not accepted as regular research papers may be offered the option of acceptance as a short paper.

### Systematization of Knowledge Papers

We also solicit Systematization of Knowledge (SoK) papers. To be suitable for publication, SoK articles must provide an added value beyond a literature review, such as novel insights, identification of research gaps, or challenges to commonly held assumptions. SoK paper submissions are limited to **20 pages** in standard LNCS format excluding references and appendices. Accepted submissions will be included in the conference proceedings. A total page restriction may apply for the printed proceedings version. Committee members are not required to read the appendices, so the full papers should be intelligible without them. The paper title for systematization of knowledge papers must begin with the text "SoK:".

## Workshop Proposals

Proposals for workshops to be held in connection with the conference are solicited. A workshop can be a full day or half day in length.

Workshop proposals should include:

-   Title
-   (Draft) Call for papers
-   Brief summary and justification, including how it would fit into the greater FC scope
-   (Tentative) Program Committee and its chair(s)
-   One-paragraph biographies for key organizers, the expected (or previous, if the workshop has been held in previous years) number of submissions, participants and acceptance rates

Workshop proposals must not be anonymous and should be sent to [fc25workshops@ifca.ai](mailto:fc25workshops@ifca.ai). Proposals received after the submission deadline will be considered on a rolling basis for any remaining slots.

## Tutorial Proposals

Proposals for tutorials to be given in connection with the conference are solicited. A tutorial can be a full day or half day in length.

Tutorial proposals should include:

-   Title
-   Description
-   Name(s) of presenter(s)
-   Brief biographies for all presenters
-   Information about previous tutorials given by the presenter(s)

Tutorial proposals must not be anonymous and should be sent to [fc25workshops@ifca.ai](mailto:fc25workshops@ifca.ai) (the same address as for workshop proposals). Proposals received after the submission deadline will be considered on a rolling basis for any remaining slots.

## Rump Session

The conference will also include the popular "rump session" held on one of the evenings in an informal, social atmosphere. The rump session is a program of short (5 minutes), informal presentations on works in progress, off-the-cuff ideas, and any other matters pertinent to the conference. Any conference attendee is welcome to submit a presentation to the Rump Session Chair (to be announced at the conference). This submission should consist of a talk title, the name of the presenter, and, if desired, a very brief abstract. Submissions may be sent via e-mail or submitted in person in the morning on the day of the session.

# FSE 2025: Call for Papers

## General Information

The 31st Fast Software Encryption Conference (FSE 2025) will take place in **Rome, Italy** from **March 17-21, 2025**. FSE 2025 is organized by the **International Association for Cryptologic Research (IACR)**.

The scope of FSE concentrates on fast and secure primitives for symmetric cryptography, including the design and analysis of block ciphers, stream ciphers, encryption schemes, hash functions, message authentication codes, (cryptographic) permutations, authenticated encryption schemes, cryptanalysis and evaluation tools, and security issues and solutions regarding their implementation.

Since 2017, FSE also solicits submissions for **Systematization of Knowledge (SoK) papers**. These papers aim at reviewing and contextualizing the existing literature in a particular area to systematize the existing knowledge. To be considered for publication, they must provide an added value beyond prior work, such as novel insights or reasonably questioning previous assumptions.

## Submission

Submissions are currently closed.

Author instructions for paper submission may be found on the submission page: [Paper Submission](/2025/papersubmission.php).

## Important Dates

*   **Conference begins:** March 16, 2025 (Note: The conference dates are March 17-21, 2025).

## Publication Model

From 2017, FSE has moved to an open-access journal/conference hybrid model. Submitted articles undergo a journal-style reviewing process. Accepted papers are published in **Gold Open Access** (free availability from day one) by the Ruhr University of Bochum in an issue of the newly established journal **IACR Transactions on Symmetric Cryptology (ToSC)**.

The FSE event will consist of presentations of the articles accepted to the journal IACR Transactions on Symmetric Cryptology, as well as invited talks and social activities.

For FSE 2025, authors can submit papers to the IACR Transactions on Symmetric Cryptology four times, every three months on a predictable schedule. Authors are notified of the decisions about two months after submission. Papers accepted for publication before the end of January 2025 will be presented at that year's conference. It is mandatory that accepted papers at the IACR Transactions on Symmetric Cryptology journal are presented at the corresponding FSE event.

## Stipends

Students whose papers have been accepted and who present their talks at the conference will have their registration waived.
A limited number of stipends are available to those unable to obtain funding to attend the conference. Students whose papers are accepted and who will present the paper themselves are encouraged to apply if such assistance is needed. Requests for stipends should be sent to the General Chairs.

# Call for Papers: GROUP 2025

## Welcome

Welcome to GROUP 2025! The ACM International Conference on Supporting Group Work (GROUP) is a premier yet intimate and welcoming venue for research on Computer Supported Cooperative Work, Sociotechnical Studies, Practice-Centered Computing, Human Computer Interaction, Computer Supported Collaborative Learning, Open Source Software, and related endeavors. GROUP 2025 will be held at the **Omni Hilton Head Oceanfront Resort, Hilton Head Island, South Carolina, USA, January 12-15, 2025**.

Key goals for the program are to encourage and facilitate researchers within CSCW, HCI for practice-centered computing, and sociotechnical studies to interact and to present recent research contributions. We also encourage research contributions from interdisciplinary groups to present work that might be difficult to place within one simple category. We are open to diverse and innovative research methods, and to contributions across broad areas such as systems, societies, participation, critique, collaboration, and human interaction. GROUP 2025 particularly encourages cross-disciplinary research across computing, social science, law, and algorithmic systems design, as well as participation from industry, academia, government, and other interested groups.

Our hope is that GROUP 2025 will be held as an in-person, physical event.

## Conference Topics

Conference topics include (but are not limited to):

*   Theoretical, methodological, and/or conceptual contributions about key concepts relevant to CSCW and HCI, including critique.
*   Social, behavioral, and computational studies of collaboration and communication.
*   Technical architectures supporting collaboration.
*   New tools/toolkits for collaborative technologies.
*   Ethnographic studies of collaborative practices.
*   Coordination and workflow technology.
*   Social computing and contexts of collaboration.
*   Studies on Open Source Software.
*   Current work in, and future visions of, practice-centered computing.
*   Social justice, ethical dimensions, and related issues in CSCW, HCI, and/or sociotechnical systems.
*   Online communities, including issues of privacy, identity, trust, and participation.
*   Cooperative knowledge management.
*   Algorithmic decision-support systems, automation, and human-AI collaboration.
*   Civic technologies and their uses.
*   Organizational issues of technology design, use, or adaptation.
*   Strategies for use of technology in business, government, and newer forms of organizations.
*   The ethical conduct of research studying group work and sociotechnical systems.
*   Emerging technologies and their design, use, or appropriation in work, home, leisure, entertainment, or education.
*   Learning at the workplace (CSCL at work, Technology-Enhanced Learning, TEL).
*   Co-located and geographically-distributed teams, global collaboration.
*   Cultural and cross-cultural collaboration and communication.
*   Mobile and wearable technologies in collaboration.
*   Innovative forms of human computer interaction for cooperative technologies.

## Submission Types

The main technical program at GROUP will welcome submissions in a variety of forms:

*   **Traditional Papers:** Report on high quality, rigorous research results.
*   **Design Fiction:** May use a variety of speculative methods to explore the futures towards which technology research and design are working.
*   **Notes:** Shorter submissions, maintaining a high level of quality and rigor while focusing on a more circumscribed result that can be presented succinctly.

Authors will have the opportunity to indicate to reviewers that their submission should be reviewed as a paper, a note, or as a design fiction.

**Typical Submission Lengths:**

*   **Note:** between 4,000 and 6,000 words
*   **Full Paper:** between 7,000 and 10,000 words
*   **Design Fiction:** between 4,000 and 10,000 words. Design fictions should clearly state that the paper is a design fiction in the abstract.

Papers exceeding typical lengths (e.g., above 12,000 words) will be examined carefully to ensure the contribution warrants the length. Papers with incommensurate lengths will be rejected.

## Important Dates

All deadlines below are at **23:59 Anywhere on Earth (AoE)**.

### Full Paper Second Wave Submissions
1.  **Abstract and Title Submission:** May 1, 2024
2.  **Submission Deadline:** May 8, 2024
3.  **1st Round Reviews and Notifications:** July 24, 2024
4.  **Resubmit Contributions Invited for Revision:** August 21, 2024
5.  **2nd Round Decisions:** October 2, 2024

### Additional CfPs
*   **Workshop Proposals Deadline:** July 15, 2024
*   **Doctoral Consortium Deadline:** September 23, 2024
*   **Posters, Demos, and Case Studies Deadline:** September 30, 2024

## Submission Guidelines

### Anonymity Requirements

Papers are subject to anonymous reviewing. Submissions must have authors’ names and affiliations removed, and avoid obvious identifying statements. Any grant information that identifies the author(s) and their institution should be removed as well. Citations to authors’ own relevant work should be done without identifying the authors. For example, “Prior work by [authors]” instead of “In our prior work.” If there are challenges with writing the paper in an anonymous way, please contact the paper chairs for advice.

Papers that clearly violate the anonymization policy, including within the supplemental materials, will be desk rejected. Please check in particular the front page, headers and footers, and the Acknowledgement section. Also, check the meta information in papers prepared using word.

GROUP does not have a policy against uploading preprints to SSRN or arXiv before they are submitted for review at the conference.

### Publication

# Call for Papers

The purpose of the International Conference on Operations Research and Enterprise Systems (ICORES) is to bring together researchers, engineers, faculty, and practitioners interested in both theoretical advances and practical applications in the field of operations research. The conference covers domain-independent methodologies and technologies, as well as practical work developed in specific application areas. ICORES focuses on real-world challenges and encourages submissions highlighting the benefits of Operations Research Methodologies and Technologies for industry and services.

Accepted papers, presented at the conference by one of the authors, will be published in the Proceedings of ICORES. Acceptance will be based on quality, relevance, and originality. Both full research reports and work-in-progress reports are welcome, with formal oral presentations and informal poster sessions.

The Paper strand provides the opportunity for researchers to present their new state-of-the-art research in Distributed Computing Systems, which makes, or has the potential to make, a significant contribution to the field.

*   Papers must be original and unpublished and must not be submitted concurrently for publication elsewhere.
*   All paper submissions should follow the IEEE 8.5″ x 11″ two-column format using 10pt fonts and the IEEE Conference template (downloadable by selecting “Conferences” in the IEEE-Template Selector: https://template-selector.ieee.org/).
*   Each submission can have up to **eleven (11) pages** (including figures, tables, appendices, and references). Papers exceeding this page limit or with smaller fonts will be desk-rejected without review.
*   The paper review process is **double-blind**. Authors are required to take all reasonable steps to preserve the anonymity of their submission. The submission must not include author information and must not include citations or discussion of related work that would make the authorship apparent.
    *   While authors can upload their paper to institutional or other preprint repositories such as arXiv.org before reviewing is complete, we generally discourage this since it places anonymity at risk. If authors decide to upload their paper to a preprint site, they must make sure that the title and abstract of their submission to ICDCS are different from the title and abstract of the preprint version, so that it is not immediately obvious that the two versions are by the same authors and with the same content.
    *   To encourage reproducibility, we encourage the authors, whenever it is possible, to include in their paper a link to an anonymised GitHub repository with all source code, scripts and data needed for the reproduction of their results.
*   For each accepted paper, **at least one author is required to pay a full author registration and attend the conference in-person to present their work on-site**. Any no-show papers will be reported to the publisher and removed from the conference proceedings. For authors with multiple papers accepted by the conference, a separate author registration is required for each paper.
*   Authors should adhere to ethic and professional standards of IEEE. Please refer to IEEE Code of Ethics and IEEE Policy of AI-Generated Text.

## Publication Opportunity

A set of highly selected IEEE ICDCS 2025 papers will be considered for publication in the IEEE Transactions on Parallel and Distributed Systems (TPDS). The selected papers will undergo an extension process, transforming them from their initial IEEE ICDCS conference format. These extended versions will then be subject to a review by an editor from IEEE TPDS.

# ICSOFT 2026: Call for Papers

The **International Conference on Software and Data Technologies (ICSoft 2026)** aims to bring together researchers, engineers, and practitioners interested in software development technologies and methodologies.

ICSOFT 2026 will be held at the **Deusto University :: Bilbao Campus** in the city of **Bilbao, Spain**.

The conference is co-located with **DATA 2026, SIMULTECH 2026, DeLTA 2026, SECRYPT 2026, and IQSOFT 2026**. Registration for ICSOFT grants free access to these co-located conferences as a non-speaker.

## Scope

The purpose of the International Conference on Software Technologies is to bring together researchers, engineers and practitioners interested on software development technologies. The conference areas are "Software Engineering and Systems Development", "Software Systems and Applications" and "Foundational and Trigger Technologies".

Papers describing original work are invited in any of the listed areas. Accepted papers, presented at the conference by one of the authors, will be published in the Proceedings of ICSOFT with an ISBN. Acceptance will be based on quality, relevance and originality. Both full research reports and work-in-progress reports are welcome. There will be both oral and poster sessions.

Special sessions, dedicated to case-studies and commercial presentations, as well as tutorials dedicated to technical/scientific topics are also envisaged. # Call for Papers

The **International Joint Conference on Computational Intelligence (IJCCI)** aims to bring together researchers, engineers, and practitioners in the areas of **Fuzzy Computation, Evolutionary Computation, and Neural Computation**, complemented by the transversal area of **Explainable AI**.

IJCCI 2025 is held in conjunction with other events: [ICINCO 2025](https://icinco.scitevents.org), [WEBIST 2025](https://webist.scitevents.org), [IN4PL 2025](https://in4pl.scitevents.org), [IC3K 2025](https://ic3k.scitevents.org), and [CoopIS 2025](https://coopis.scitevents.org). Registration to IJCCI allows free access to these co-located conferences (as a non-speaker).

The conference offers hybrid support, allowing speakers to present remotely if unable to travel to the venue.

## Scope and Conference Areas

The purpose of IJCCI is to bring together researchers, engineers, and practitioners on the areas of Fuzzy Computation, Evolutionary Computation, and Neural Computation, complemented by the transversal area of Explainable AI. IJCCI is composed of several co-located conferences, each specialized in at least one of the aforementioned main knowledge areas.

**Conference Areas:** Available soon.

## Keynote Speakers

*   **Luís Paulo Reis**, University of Porto, Portugal
*   **Pietro Ducange**, University of Pisa, Italy
*   **Fei Liu**, City University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong
*   **Henry Prakken**, Utrecht University, Netherlands

## Paper Submission

Authors should submit a paper in English, carefully checked for correct grammar and spelling, addressing one or several of the conference areas or topics. Each paper should clearly indicate the nature of its technical/scientific contribution, and the problems, domains or environments to which it is applicable.

To facilitate the double-blind paper evaluation method, authors are kindly requested to produce and provide the paper **WITHOUT any reference to any of the authors** including the authors’ personal details, the acknowledgments section of the paper and any other reference that may disclose the authors’ identity.

Only original papers should be submitted. Authors are advised to read [INSTICC's ethical norms regarding plagiarism and self-plagiarism](https://www.scitepress.org/PublishedPapers/2025) thoroughly before submitting and must make sure that their submissions do not substantially overlap work which has been published elsewhere or simultaneously submitted to a journal or another conference with proceedings. Papers that contain any form of plagiarism will be rejected without reviews.

Authors can submit their work in the form of a:

*   **Regular Paper**: representing completed and validated research.
*   **Position Paper**: portraying a short report of work in progress or an arguable opinion about an issue discussing ideas, facts, situations, methods, procedures or results of scientific research focused on one of the conference topic areas.

All papers must be submitted through the online submission platform **PRIMORIS** and should follow the instructions and templates that can be found under [Guidelines and Templates](https://www.scitepress.org/PublishedPapers/2025). After the paper submission has been successfully completed, authors will receive an automatic confirmation e-mail.

## Special Sessions

# Call for Papers

## Scope

The Internet of Things (IoT) is transforming how devices and systems interact, enabling smart applications across healthcare, manufacturing, energy, transportation, and smart cities. This rapid growth generates vast, diverse, and real-time data — Big Data — which demands advanced techniques for analysis, storage, security, and intelligent decision-making.

The convergence of IoT, Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (AI), and Machine Learning creates new opportunities for actionable insights, autonomous systems, and enhanced user experiences. In particular, emerging technologies such as Generative AI offer unprecedented capabilities for smart, connected environments.

However, security, privacy, trust, and ethical AI remain critical challenges. The conference invites research contributions, practical solutions, and case studies addressing these concerns and advancing the state of the art in IoT and Big Data ecosystems.

IoTDBS brings together researchers, practitioners, and industry experts to explore innovations, trends, and challenges shaping the future of smart systems and data-driven applications. Maintaining a high level of security and privacy in IoT environments is crucial, and we welcome recommendations, solutions, demonstrations, and best practices addressing all aspects of security and privacy in IoT and Big Data.

## Conference Areas

1.  **AI AND IOT SECURITY**
2.  **BIG DATA RESEARCH**
3.  **EMERGING SERVICES AND ANALYTICS**
4.  **INTERNET OF THINGS (IOT) APPLICATIONS**
5.  **INTERNET OF THINGS (IOT) FUNDAMENTALS**

## Paper Submission

Authors can submit their work in the form of a **complete paper** or an **abstract**. Accepted abstracts are presented but not published in the proceedings.

Complete papers can be submitted as:
*   **Regular Paper:** Representing completed and validated research.
*   **Position Paper:** Portraying a short report of work in progress or an arguable opinion about an issue.

Authors should submit a paper in English, carefully checked for correct grammar and spelling, addressing one or several of the conference areas or topics. Each paper should clearly indicate the nature of its technical/scientific contribution, and the problems, domains or environments to which it is applicable.

To facilitate the double-blind paper evaluation method, authors are kindly requested to produce and provide the paper **WITHOUT any reference to any of the authors**, including personal details, acknowledgments, or other identifying references.

# Call for Papers: SAT 2025

The 28th International Conference on Theory and Applications of Satisfiability Testing (SAT 2025) will take place from **August 12-15, 2025**, with workshops held on **August 10-11, 2025**, at the **University of Glasgow in Glasgow, Scotland**.

## Scope

SAT 2025 is dedicated to all aspects of the theory and applications of propositional satisfiability, broadly construed. This includes paradigms such as Boolean optimization (e.g., MaxSAT, pseudo-Boolean/PB solving), quantified Boolean formulas (QBF), satisfiability modulo theories (SMT), model counting, constraint programming (CP), and integer linear programming (ILP) with clear connections to Boolean-level reasoning.

The conference will be co-located with the 31st International Conference on Principles and Practice of Constraint Programming (CP 2025), the 18th International Symposium on Combinatorial Search (SoCS), and the 23rd International Workshop on Satisfiability Modulo Theories (SMT).

## Topics of Interest

Topics of interest for SAT 2025 include, but are not limited to:

*   Theoretical advances (algorithms, proof complexity, parameterized complexity, other complexity issues)
*   Practical search algorithms
*   Knowledge compilation
*   Implementation-level details of SAT and SMT solving tools and SAT/SMT-based systems
*   Problem encodings and reformulations
*   Applications (novel domains and improvements to existing approaches)
*   Case studies and reports on scientific findings based on rigorous experimentation

## Out of Scope

Papers claiming to resolve significant long-standing open problems in mathematics or computer science (e.g., Millennium Prize problems) are out of scope due to insufficient review time.

## Paper Categories

Submissions are invited in three categories:

*   **Long papers:** 9 to 15 pages (excluding references and appendices). These should contain original research with sufficient detail for assessment. Authors are encouraged to provide data and implementation for verification.
*   **Short papers:** Up to 8 pages (excluding references and appendices). These should also contain original research. The length should be chosen based on the space needed to describe the contribution.
*   **Tool papers:** Up to 8 pages (excluding references and appendices). These should report on the design and implementation of novel tools (solvers, preprocessors, systems). Significant enhancements to previously published tools are expected.

## Submission Guidelines

*   Submissions must not be under review or submitted elsewhere concurrently.
*   Submissions must be made via href="https://easychair.org/conferences/?conf=sat2025" - EasyChair .
*   Papers must be formatted in the LIPIcs LaTeX style, available href="https://submission.dagstuhl.de/series/details/LIPIcs#author" - here .
*   Submissions must be in PDF format.
*   The reviewing process is **single-blind**.
*   SAT 2025 will use the ACM CoI policy for managing conflicts of interest.
*   Authors may submit supplementary material (proofs, examples, software, data) for reviewers' discretion.
*   One author of each accepted paper is expected to present the paper at the conference.
*   Withdrawal of submissions is only allowed before the author response period begins.

The 24th annual Symposium on Computer Animation (SCA) will take place in **Vancouver, Canada**, from **August 7 to August 10, 2025**.

## About SCA

SCA is the premier forum for innovations in the theory, software, and technology of computer animation. It is a focused and intimate gathering of researchers and practitioners working on all aspects of time-based phenomena. The conference features a single track program with paper sessions, poster presentations, panel discussions, and keynote talks, fostering community interaction.
